I'm not sure how to say this politely, but you more or less entirely misunderstood Evangelion. Eva isn't about everything being futile or doomed to fall or apart. It's about hope. Hope in spite of hardship, in spite of misunderstanding and pain. In both the TV ending and EoE, Shinji resolves to keep trying to live and find happiness as an individual human. He acknowledges the difficulties that entails and even concedes that he still hates himself. But he has hope that he can one day learn to love himself and connect with other people and so he's willing to keep trying.
TTGL isn't a refutation of Evangelion, they have almost exactly the same message. It's more of a spiritual successor. The one thing I'd say you got right is the difference in the support the protagonist has. Evangelion is, for the most part, an individual struggle for each of the characters, not just Shinji. A great deal of their suffering is due to them being atomized and alone. And Shinji's big resolution in the end is largely about not continuing to let his self hatred and the fear that is born from it stand in the way of trying to connect with other people. Gurren Lagann basically starts from this point. Simon has the doubts and low opinion of himself that Shinji retains even through the end of Evangelion. But Simon is more willing to open himself up to and have faith in other people, which is what Shinji was at least trying to do in the end. Simon's growth isn't entirely due to external factors. While both Kamina and Nia make it their personal mission to build him up, Simon has to make the first move with both of them. This is especially true with Kamina. Simon only ended up with Kamina because he was willing to take the risk of believing in him when they first tried to escape the village. Shinji did try and connect with others throughout Eva, but the fear of making himself truly vulnerable always held him back. Simon is what would happen if Shinji was able to overcome that. Even the extreme optimism of Gurren Lagann in immediately rewarding Simon's faith with the best friend anyone could ever ask for is a fitting continuation from Evangelion's cynical realism. It's representative of the different perspective granted by hope and faith in yourself and others, of the change from fixating on the negative to celebrating the positive. Both shows are ultimately part of the same journey.
Also, as an aside, you take things too literally. The technobabble in Evangelion is every bit as irrelevant as it is in Gurren Lagann. That's a Gainax thing in general. The specific minutiae of the setting is never actually important and only exists to support the characters' story. Ritsuko babbling off a bunch of nonsense is just handled more seriously because the show itself is more serious in tone. And Shinji choking Asuka in EoE isn't about him hating her. In that moment Asuka is the only other person on Earth. She is the representative of the "other" in contrast to Shinji's "self". Shinji choking her after rejecting instrumentality is demonstrating that merely choosing to keep living and hoping doesn't magically fix everything instantly. Shinji's desire to connect with others is still complicated by his bitterness and incompetence at forming healthy relationships. And Asuka caressing Shinji's cheek followed by her disgusted remark maintain the promise of hope by showing that human connection isn't beyond reach while still remaining grounded in the reality that a change in outlook isn't going to stop people from feeling negative things towards you.

The whole theme of the show is how no one person, on their own, can do the impossible, but by everyone contributing a little bit of progress, one by one, little by little, we creep and drill our way from the lowest of lows to effective godhood.
Kamina's father inspired Kamina. So Kamina did the job of Hero and Leader, essentially "stealing the spotlight" of the whole show until it literally killed him. "Who the hell do you think I am", in a way, can be taken to be asking, "Do you really think I'm the Leader? Do you really think I'm the Main Character? No, Simon is the Main Character of this show, I'm just his opening act!" And, thus, he keeps the "seat warm" until Simon is inspired enough to take up that Main Character mantle.
Kamina looks at the world through literal rose tinted glasses; but Nia's eyes are rose colored flowers. She doesn't need to wear something extra to change how she sees the world; to her, the world is flowers, it is beautiful and rosy, even in its darkest and bleakest. So both she and Kamina, each in their own way, inspire Simon to totally fulfill his Leadership and Heroic role in the story.
Amd it doesn't even stop there. Simon, in turn inspires Kitan to become the "Hero of His Own Story". Kitan hijacks the Heroic Sacrifice role for himself, having been inspired by Simon, Kamina, and all the rest. And that, in turn inspires others, including passing inspiration back to Simon. Simon no longer sees the world just through rosy glasses, but Kitan's sacrifice forces him to literally "look to the stars" as he transforms the standard Wing-Glasses from Kamina into the Star-Glasses in honor of Kitan. If he can't have "stars in his eyes", he'll do the next best thing and wear them on his face.
And, by the end of the series, when his role as a Hero and as a Leader is over and done, he gets a moment of pure happiness, being able to marry Nia before she completely fades away. He absolutely has the Spiral Power to bring her back, but that's precisely the danger the Anti-spiral had warned him about; unfettered, self-serving, irresponsible abuse of Spiral Power would eventually lead to the destruction of everything. Who was he to say his and Nia's personal happiness was more important than the happiness of everyone else in the whole universe; after all, he's no God, he's just a digger.
And so, he in turn has inspired the next generation, handed the story off to the "story untold". And there never needed to be a "next generation" series, the likes of "Boruto" any more than we needed a prequel series that showed the origins of the previous war against the Anti-Spiral. Because there's neither beginning nor end; it's an infinite, twisting path from past, through present, on to the future. Amd Gurren Lagann was just one little window, a slice of that infinity, meant to inspire us, the viewers, to go on to become our own Heroes and Leaders in our own stories.

My entire perspective on brothers changed when I watched Kamina die. It made me have to accept that, despite his age and similarities, my own brother's life isn't a guarantee, despite him meaning more to me than even my parents, and that sometimes life hands you a change that makes you want to actually die.

That's because, until Simon grows up, Kamina IS the pinnacle of inspiration. He knows the unthinkable, he breaks the unbreakable, he IS spiral power. His flaws mean nothing in his last moments. He is a hero, a martyr, and a display of the cost. Simon accepts this far down the road as he has to say goodbye to Nia. He acted with his heart on his sleeve and knew there would be a price to pay, just like Kamina had to pay with his life to show Simon and the team the way. It was never about just winning, or just fighting, it was about proving a point; that with all of the limits of humanity, they are still capable of boosting each other to before-impossible heights. Kamina never lost. He only paid his life for a chance for others. He accepted death because he believed in the drill, Simon's drill, the drill that will create the heavens.

Kamina was never meant to be some impossibly strong or capable person. He's simply who he is: the big brother to Simon. He goes as far as to sacrifice himself for his brother and friends. With this, his flaws no longer matter. He was strong to the end, and that's what makes him a hero. Beyond this, he taught Simon strength and confidence, a change that altered the very universe. Without Kamina, there is no Gurren Lagann, but in the absence of Kamina is where Team Dai Gurren understands the reality they face. Many may die. Maybe even everyone. But it's a fight worth fighting, and Kamina proved that to everyone.

The issue with Nia's death is manyfold. For one, she was a creation of the antispirals. Which means that when she disappears in the wedding, she is not dying, she stopped existing.

Now, there is very big difference between those two in Gurren Lagann universe. If you die, you are not necessarily gone, an essence of you lives on, both overall and in the heart of people.

But Nia was built out of the antithesis of that idea. Her very essence was built to... simply break down after a while. Like a soulless tool.

Sure she may have a soul, but that soul was essentially built of the opposite essence of what humans were made out of. Meaning, even when Simon dies, their souls will never be reunited.

So yeah, I have a lot of issues regarding that part of the ending. Both morally and logically considering the in-universe logic of things.

It should have been just matter of fact to create some sort of antispiral device that would sustain Nia's existence until they found a way to polarise her from antispiral to spiral energy.
